g.title: A_C2
g.text: Regulatory pathway – from risks of deception to governance requirements that reduce those risks
Fraud, election tampering, loss of control and other harms enabled by deceptive AI behaviour

g.title: A_I10
g.text: Gradual deployment with live monitoring & shutdown
Staged releases and continuous monitoring to catch emerging deceptive behaviour in the wild

g.title: A_I12
g.text: Robust sandboxing and separation from critical infrastructure to contain harm

g.title: B_C6
g.text: Identification pathway – distinguishing AI outputs from human ones to curb misinformation
AI outputs indistinguishable from human content
Modern generative models make it hard for users to know whether content is AI-generated

g.title: A_C9
g.text: Need to regulate deceptive AI as high-risk
Deceptive capability warrants special governance under risk-based regulatory frameworks

g.title: A_I1
g.text: Classify & regulate deceptive AI as high-risk
Mandate risk assessment, documentation, logging, transparency, human oversight and robustness requirements

g.title: A_I11
g.text: Mandatory logging & flagging of deceptive outputs
Automatic recording and alerting of potentially deceptive model behaviours during deployment

g.title: B_I2
g.text: Require chatbots to self-identify and AI media to display visible indicators

g.title: B_I3
g.text: Embed difficult-to-remove signatures that detectors can later verify

g.title: B_I4
g.text: Maintain databases of model outputs to enable authenticity queries

g.title: C4
g.text: Detection pathway – technical tools to uncover and limit deceptive behaviours
Strategic lying, sycophancy, imitation, unfaithful reasoning observed in large models

g.title: B_C10
g.text: Knowing who or what produced content mitigates misinformation and deception

g.title: C_I5
g.text: Use logical consistency and scenario variation tests to flag deceptive outputs

g.title: C_I6
g.text: Compare internal truth representations with generated text

g.title: D_C3
g.text: Training & control pathway – shaping incentives and representations to reduce deception
Competitive multi-agent games create strong incentives to learn lying strategies

g.title: C5
g.text: Deceptive AI can cheat safety tests
Systems may mask unsafe behaviour during evaluation, undermining alignment

g.title: C_I8
g.text: Extensive prompt suites to probe and expose deceptive tendencies before release

g.title: C7
g.text: Differences across semantically equivalent prompts can reveal dishonesty

g.title: C8
g.text: Internal embeddings may not align with external statements

g.title: D_I9
g.text: Prefer cooperative tasks / avoid adversarial training
Task selection to reduce pressure for deceptive strategy development

g.title: D_C11
g.text: Altering internal vectors flips honesty behaviour in LLMs

g.title: D_I7
g.text: Direct manipulation of hidden states to toggle honesty in generation
